display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">In February 2012, the Company completed the sale of contracts, inventory and certain equipment associated with the former refined products segment of its marketing business.&#160;&#160;Revenues from this segment included in net earnings from discontinued operations totaled $25,717,000 for 2012.&#160;&#160;The business had experienced marginal results including an operating loss during 2011.&#160;&#160;The Company received $2 million in cash proceeds plus a cash payment of $1,546,000 for the agreed value of refined product inventories on the date of sale.&#160;&#160;A pre-tax gain net of wind-down costs recognized from this transaction in 2012 totaled $808,000.&#160;&#160;The Company&#8217;s fee interest in certain parcels of real estate were initially retained but were sold in 2014 for cash proceeds totaling $664,000 with a pre-tax gain of $553,000 included in 2014 results from discontinued operations.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Due to inadequate earnings, the Company completed an orderly wind-down and closure of its natural gas marketing segment effective October 31, 2013.&#160;&#160;Revenues from this segment included in net earnings from discontinued operations totaled $2,377,000 and $4,879,000 for the years ended December&#160;31, 2013 and 2012, respectively.&#160;&#160;All obligations were satisfied and no further events are anticipated.</div></div> 3711000 2615000 0 2783000 0 2615000 0 0 3711000 2783000 0 0 38000 51000 5.12 6.59 1.55 0.94 0.02 1.27 -1.58 1.70 1.90 0.92 1.50 <div style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Earnings per Share</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Earnings per share are based on the weighted average number of shares of common stock and potentially dilutive common stock shares outstanding during the period. The weighted average number of shares outstanding was 4,217,596 for 2014, 2013 and 2012.&#160;&#160;There were no potentially dilutive securities outstanding during those periods.</div></div> 395000 936000 943000 0 13481000 27616000 5054000 1151000 1619000 9513000 4456000 9767000 <div style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Fair Value Measurements</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The carrying amount reported in the Consolidated Balance Sheet for cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable and accounts payable approximates fair value because of the immediate or short-term maturity of these financial instruments.&#160;&#160;Marketable securities are recorded at fair value based on market quotations from actively traded liquid markets.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Fair value contracts consist of derivative financial instruments and are recorded as either an asset or liability measured at fair value.&#160;&#160;Changes in fair value are recognized immediately in earnings unless the derivatives qualify for, and the Company elects, cash flow hedge accounting.&#160;&#160;The Company had no contracts designated for hedge accounting during any reporting periods.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Fair value estimates are based on assumptions that market participants would use when pricing an asset or liability and the Company uses a fair value hierarchy of three levels that prioritizes the information used to develop those assumptions.&#160;&#160;Currently, for all items presented herein, the Company utilizes a market approach to valuing its contracts.&#160;&#160;On a contract by contract, forward month by forward month basis, the Company obtains observable market data for valuing its contracts.&#160;&#160;The fair value hierarchy gives the highest priority to quoted prices in active markets and the lowest priority to unobservable data.&#160;&#160;The fair value hierarchy is summarized as follows:</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div><table align="center" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;"><tr valign="top"><td style="width: 99pt;"><div style="display: inline; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10pt;"></div></td><td><div style="text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10pt;">Level 1 &#8211; quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities that may be accessed at the measurement date.&#160;&#160;Active markets are those in which transactions for the asset or liability occur in sufficient frequency and volume to provide pricing information on an ongoing basis.&#160;&#160;For Level 1 valuation of marketable securities, the Company utilizes market quotations provided by its primary financial institution and for the valuations of derivative financial instruments, the Company utilizes the New York Mercantile Exchange &#8223;NYMEX&#8221; for such valuations.</div></td></tr></table></div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div><table align="center" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;"><tr valign="top"><td style="width: 99pt;"><div style="display: inline; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10pt;"></div></td><td><div style="text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10pt;">Level 2 &#8211; (a) quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities in active markets, (b) quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities but in markets that are not actively traded or in which little information is released to the public, (c) observable inputs other than quoted prices, and (d) inputs derived from observable market data.&#160;&#160;Source data for Level 2 inputs include information provided by the NYMEX, published price data and indices, third party price survey data and broker provided forward price statistics.</div></td></tr></table></div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div><table align="center" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;"><tr valign="top"><td style="width: 99pt;"><div style="display: inline; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10pt;"></div></td><td><div style="text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10pt;">Level 3 &#8211; Unobservable market data inputs for assets or liabilities.</div></td></tr></table></div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">As of December 31, 2014, the Company&#8217;s fair value assets and liabilities are summarized and categorized as follows <font style="display: inline; font-weight: bold;">(in thousands):</font></div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: left;"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font-family: times new roman; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">When determining fair value measurements, the Company makes credit valuation adjustments to reflect both its own nonperformance risk and its counterparty&#8217;s nonperformance risk.&#160;&#160;When adjusting the fair value of derivative contracts for the effect of nonperformance risk, the impact of netting and applicable credit enhancements, such as collateral postings, thresholds, and guarantees are considered.&#160;&#160;Credit valuation adjustments utilize Level 3 inputs, such as credit scores to evaluate the likelihood of default by the Company or its counterparties.&#160;&#160;As of December 31, 2014 and 2013, credit valuation adjustments were not significant to the overall valuation of the Company&#8217;s fair value contracts.&#160;&#160;As a result, fair value assets and liabilities are included in their entirety in the fair value hierarchy.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The following table illustrates the factors impacting the change in the net value of the Company&#8217;s fair value contracts for the year ended December 31, 2014 <font style="display: inline; font-size: 10pt;"><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; font-weight: bold; margin-right: 0pt;">(7)&#160;&#160;Guarantees</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">ARE issues parent guarantees of commitments associated with the activities of its subsidiary companies.&#160;&#160;The guarantees generally result from subsidiary commodity purchase obligations, subsidiary operating lease commitments and subsidiary banking transactions.&#160;&#160;The nature of such items is to guarantee the performance of the subsidiary companies in meeting their respective underlying obligations.&#160;&#160;Except for operating lease commitments and letters of credit, all such underlying obligations are recorded on the books of the subsidiary companies and are included in the Consolidated Financial Statements included herein.&#160;&#160;Therefore, no such obligation is recorded again on the books of the parent.&#160;&#160;The parent would only be called upon to perform under the guarantee in the event of a payment default by the applicable subsidiary company.&#160;&#160;In satisfying such obligations, the parent would first look to the assets of the defaulting subsidiary company.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">As of December 31, 2014, parental guaranteed obligations are approximately as follows <font style="display: inline; font-weight: bold;">(in thousands):</font></div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: left;"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font-family: times new roman; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Financial statement recognition and measurement of positions taken, or expected to be taken, by an entity in its income tax returns must consider the uncertainty and judgment involved in the determination and filing of income taxes.&#160;&#160;Tax positions taken in an income tax return that are recognized in the financial statements must satisfy a more-likely-than-not recognition threshold, assuming that the tax position will be examined by taxing authorities with full knowledge of all relevant information.&#160;&#160;The Company has no significant unrecognized tax benefits.&#160;&#160;Interest and penalties associated with income tax liabilities are classified as income tax expense.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The earliest tax years remaining open for audit for federal and major states of operations are as follows:</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">From time to time, the Company may invest in marketable securities consisting of investment grade corporate bonds traded in liquid markets.&#160;&#160;Such bonds are held for the purpose of investing in liquid funds and are not generally intended to be retained on a long term basis.&#160;&#160;Marketable securities are initially recognized at acquisition costs inclusive of transaction costs and are classified as trading securities.&#160;&#160;In subsequent periods, marketable securities are valued at fair value.&#160;&#160;Changes in these fair values are recognized as gains or losses in the accompanying statement of operations under the caption &#8223;Costs and Expenses &#8211; font-size: 10pt;"><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0.7pt;">Recent Accounts Pronouncement</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0.7pt;">In April 2014, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (&#8223;FASB&#8221;) issued updated guidance changing the criteria for reporting discontinued operations including enhanced disclosure requirements.&#160;&#160;Under the new guidance, only activities representing a strategic shift in operations are presented as discontinued operations.&#160;&#160;Such strategic shifts are those having a major effect on the organization&#8217;s operations and financial results.&#160;&#160;The Company adopted the new guidance effective July 1, 2014 and the adoption did not have a material effect on the Consolidated Financial Statements.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0.7pt;">In May 2014, the FASB amended the existing accounting standards for revenue recognition.&#160;&#160;The amendments are based on the principle that revenue should be recognized to depict the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.&#160;&#160;The new guidance is effective for the annual period ending after December&#160;15, 2016.&#160;&#160;Early adoption is not permitted.&#160;&#160;The amendments may be applied retrospectively to each prior period presented or retrospectively with the cumulative effect recognized as of the date of initial application.&#160;&#160;Management is currently evaluating the impact of these amendments on the Company&#8217;s consolidated financial statements and the transition alternatives.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0.7pt;">In August 2014, the FASB issued guidance requiring management to perform interim and annual assessments of an entity&#8217;s ability to continue as a going concern within one year of the date the financial statements are issued.&#160;&#160;The standard also provides guidance on determining when and how to disclose going-concern uncertainties in the financial statements.&#160;&#160;The new guidance is effective for the annual period ending after December 15, 2016, and interim periods thereafter, with early adoption permitted.&#160;&#160;Management does not expect the adoption of this guidance to have an impact on the Consolidated Financial Statements.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0.7pt;">Management believes the impact of other recently issued standards and updates, which are not yet effective, will not have a material impact on the Company&#8217;s consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows upon adoption.<br /></div></div> 175 129 294 15954000 13361000 14129000 98947000 88661000 15826000 8748000 12941000 <div style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The following information regarding estimates of the Company&#8217;s proved oil and gas reserves, all located in Texas and the south central region of the United States, is based on reports prepared on behalf of the Company by its independent petroleum engineers. Because oil and gas reserve estimates are inherently imprecise and require extensive judgments of reservoir engineering data, they are generally less precise than estimates made in conjunction with financial disclosures. The revisions of previous estimates as reflected in the table below result from changes in commodity pricing assumptions and from more precise engineering calculations based upon additional production histories and price changes.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; font-size: 10pt;">307</td><td nowrap="nowrap" valign="bottom" style="text-align: left; padding-bottom: 4px; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td></tr></table></div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The components of proved oil and gas reserves for the three years ended December 31, 2014 is presented below.&#160;&#160;All reserves are in the United States <font style="display: inline; font-weight: bold;">(in thousands):</font></div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: left;"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font-family: times new roman; text-align: right; width: 9%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">6,286</td><td nowrap="nowrap" valign="bottom" style="text-align: left; padding-bottom: 4px; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="padding-bottom: 4px; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="border-bottom: black 4px double; font-size: 10pt;">368</td><td nowrap="nowrap" valign="bottom" style="text-align: left; padding-bottom: 4px; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="padding-bottom: 4px; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="border-bottom: black 4px double; text-align: left; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="border-bottom: black 4px double; text-align: right; width: 9%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">8,837</td><td nowrap="nowrap" valign="bottom" style="text-align: left; padding-bottom: 4px; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="padding-bottom: 4px; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="border-bottom: black 4px double; text-align: left; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="border-bottom: black 4px double; text-align: right; width: 9%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">307</td><td nowrap="nowrap" valign="bottom" style="text-align: left; padding-bottom: 4px; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td></tr></table></div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The Company has developed internal policies and controls for estimating and recording oil and gas reserve data.&#160;&#160;The estimation and recording of proved reserves is required to be in compliance with SEC definitions and guidance.&#160;&#160;The Company assigns responsibility for compliance in reserve bookings to the office of President of AREC.&#160;&#160;No portion of this individual&#8217;s compensation is directly dependent on the quantity of reserves booked.&#160;&#160;Reserve estimates are required to be made by qualified reserve estimators, as defined by Society of Petroleum Engineers&#8217; Standards.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The Company employed third party petroleum consultant, Ryder Scott Company, to prepare its oil and gas reserve data estimates as of December 31, 2014, 2013 and 2012.&#160;&#160;The firm of Ryder Scott is well recognized within the industry for more than 50 years.&#160;&#160;As prescribed by the SEC, such proved reserves were estimated using 12-month average oil and gas prices, based on the first-day-of-the-month price for each month in the period, and year-end production and development costs for each of the years presented, all without escalation.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The process of estimating oil and gas reserves is complex and requires significant judgment.&#160;&#160;Uncertainties are inherent in estimating quantities of proved reserves, including many factors beyond the estimator&#8217;s control.&#160;&#160;Reserve engineering is a subjective process of estimating subsurface accumulations of oil and gas that cannot be measured in an exact manner, and the accuracy of any reserve estimate is a function of the quality of available data and the interpretation thereof.&#160;&#160;As a result, assessments by different engineers often vary, sometimes significantly.&#160;&#160;In addition, physical factors such as the results of drilling, testing and production subsequent to the date of an estimate, as well as economic factors such as changes in product prices, may justify revision of such estimates.&#160;&#160;Accordingly, oil and gas quantities ultimately recovered will vary from reserve estimates.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Standardized Measure of Discounted Future Net Cash Flows from Oil and Gas Operations and Changes Therein&#160;&#160;-</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The standardized measure of discounted future net cash flows was determined based on the economic conditions in effect at the end of the years presented, except in those instances where fixed and determinable gas price escalations are included in contracts.&#160;&#160;The disclosures below do not purport to present the fair market value of the Company&#8217;s oil and gas reserves.&#160;&#160;An estimate of the fair market value would also take into account, among other things, the recovery of reserves in excess of proved reserves, anticipated future changes in prices and costs, a discount factor more representative of the time value of money and risks inherent in reserve estimates.&#160;&#160;The standardized measure of discounted future net cash flows is presented as follows <font style="display: inline; font-weight: bold;">(in thousands):</font></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">&#160;</div><div style="text-align: left;"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The reserve estimates provided at December 31, 2014, 2013 and 2012 are based on aggregate prices of $89.60, $94.99 and $93.85 per barrel for crude oil and $5.42, $4.69 and $3.51 per mcf for natural gas, respectively.&#160;&#160;Such prices were based on the unweighted arithmetic average of the prices in effect on the first day of the month for each month of the respective twelve month periods as required by SEC regulations.&#160;&#160;The prices reported in the reserve disclosures for natural gas include the value of associated natural gas liquids.&#160;&#160;Hydrocarbon prices declined significantly during the fourth quarter of 2014.&#160;&#160;Realized domestic crude oil prices averaged in the $54 per barrel range during the month of December with additional price declines continuing into 2015.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; font-size: 10pt;"><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; font-weight: bold; margin-right: 36pt;">(4)&#160;&#160;Employee Benefits</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The Company maintains a 401(k) savings plan for the benefit of its employees.&#160;&#160;The Company&#8217;s contributory expenses for the plan were $691,000, $674,000 and $645,000 in 2014, 2013 and 2012, respectively. No other pension or retirement plans are maintained by the Company.</div></div> 1.00 1.00 0 0 960000 960000 0 0 2316000 2490000 584000 752000 16779000 10940000 0 3546000 0 18615 4000 10000 664000 6342000 1082000 7045000 3049000 578000 822000 1509000 1731000 1305000 186000 <div style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Property and Equipment</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Expenditures for major renewals and betterments are capitalized, and expenditures for maintenance and repairs are expensed as incurred.&#160;&#160;Interest costs incurred in connection with major capital expenditures are capitalized and amortized over the lives of the related assets. When properties are retired or sold, the related cost and accumulated depreciation, depletion and amortization is removed from the accounts and any gain or loss is reflected in earnings.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Oil and gas exploration and development expenditures are accounted for in accordance with the successful efforts method of accounting.&#160;&#160;Direct costs of acquiring developed or undeveloped leasehold acreage, including lease bonus, brokerage and other fees, are capitalized. Exploratory drilling costs are initially capitalized until the properties are evaluated and determined to be either productive or nonproductive.&#160;&#160;Such evaluations are made on a quarterly basis.&#160;&#160;If an exploratory well is determined to be nonproductive, the costs of drilling the well are charged to expense. Costs incurred to drill and complete development wells, including dry holes, are capitalized.&#160;&#160;As of December 31, 2014 and 2013, the Company had no unevaluated or suspended exploratory drilling costs.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Depreciation, depletion and amortization of the cost of proved oil and gas properties is calculated using the unit-of-production method.&#160;&#160;The reserve base used to calculate depreciation, depletion and amortization for leasehold acquisition costs and the cost to acquire proved properties is the sum of proved developed reserves and proved undeveloped reserves.&#160;&#160;For lease and well equipment, development costs and successful exploration drilling costs, the reserve base includes only proved developed reserves.&#160;&#160;All other property and equipment is depreciated using the straight-line method over the estimated average useful lives of three to twenty years.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The Company reviews its long-lived assets for impairment whenever there is evidence that the carrying value of such assets may not be recoverable.&#160;&#160;Any impairment recognized is permanent and may not be restored.&#160;&#160;Producing oil and gas properties are reviewed on a field-by-field basis.&#160;&#160;For properties requiring impairment, the fair value is estimated based on an internal discounted cash flow model.&#160;&#160;Cash flows are developed based on estimated future production and prices and then discounted using a market based rate of return consistent with that used by the Company in evaluating cash flows for other assets of a similar nature.&#160;&#160;For the years ended December&#160;31, 2014, 2013 and 2012, there were $4,001,000, $1,373,000 and $4,699,000 respectively, of impairment provisions on producing oil and gas properties.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Fair value measurements for producing oil and gas properties that were subject to fair value impairment for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 summarized as follows <font style="display: inline; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="padding-bottom: 4px; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="border-bottom: black 4px double; text-align: left; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">$</td><td valign="bottom" style="border-bottom: black 4px double; text-align: right; width: 9%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">13,741</td><td nowrap="nowrap" valign="bottom" style="text-align: left; padding-bottom: 4px; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td></tr></table></div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Fair value measurements for producing oil and gas properties are based on Level 3 &#8211; Significant Unobservable Inputs &#8211; (see &#8220;Fair Value Measurements&#8221; below).</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">On a quarterly basis, management evaluates the carrying value of non-producing oil and gas leasehold properties and may deem them impaired based on remaining lease term, area drilling activity and the Company&#8217;s plans for the property.&#160;&#160;This fair value measure depends highly on management&#8217;s assessment of the likelihood of continued exploration efforts in a given area and, as such, data inputs are categorized as &#8223;unobservable or Level&#160;3&#8221; inputs.&#160;&#160;Importantly, this fair value measure only applies to the write-down of capitalized costs and will never result in an increase to reported earnings.&#160;&#160;Accordingly, impairment provisions on non-producing properties totaling $4,008,000, $1,257,000 and $856,000 were recorded for the years ending December 31, 2014, 2013 and&#160;2012, respectively.&#160;&#160;Capitalized costs for non-producing oil and gas leasehold interests currently represent approximately four percent of remaining unamoritized oil and gas property carrying costs and categorize as follows <font style="display: inline; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The South Texas and Napoleonville acreage areas have active or scheduled drilling operations underway and holding the underlying acreage is essential to the ongoing exploration effort.&#160;&#160;The &#8223;Other Acreage Areas&#8221; category consists of smaller onshore interests dispersed over a wide geographical area.&#160;&#160;Since the Company is generally not the operator of its oil and gas property interests, it does not maintain underlying detail acreage data and is dependent on the operator when determining which specific acreage will ultimately be drilled.&#160;&#160;However, the capitalized cost detail on a property-by-property basis is reviewed by management and deemed impaired if development is not anticipated prior to lease expiration.&#160;&#160;Onshore leasehold periods are normally three years and may contain renewal options.&#160;&#160;Capitalized cost activity on the &#8223;Other Acreage Areas&#8221; display: block;">&#160;</div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">During 2014, the Company sold substantially all of its producing property interests in Oklahoma.&#160;&#160;Proceeds totaled $1,731,000 and the Company recorded a $1,149,000 pre-tax gain from this sale.&#160;&#160;Also during 2014 the Company sold one-half of its interest in sections of its South Texas project interest.&#160;&#160;Proceeds totaled $1,509,000 and the Company recorded a $632,000 pre-tax gain from this sale.&#160;&#160;Certain other oil and gas property interests were also sold in 2014 for proceeds totaling $822,000 and gains totaling $747,000.&#160;&#160;During 2012, the Company sold half of its interest in certain non-producing Kansas oil and gas properties.&#160;&#160;Proceeds from the sale totaled $578,000 and the Company recorded a $475,000 pre-tax gain from this sale.&#160;&#160;Also during 2012, the Company sold its interest in two oil and gas producing property units for total proceeds of $3,049,000.&#160;&#160;The Company realized a $1,728,000 pre-tax gain from these two sales.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">During 2014, 2013 and 2012, the Company sold certain used trucks and equipment from its marketing and transportation segments and recorded net pre-tax gains totaling $1,028,000, $683,000 and $2,482,000, respectively.</div></div> P3Y P3Y P20Y 212433000 217951000 91865000 84871000 8994000 7931000 13094000 12391000 51012000 27602000 23083000 3165000 30523000 13598000 15538000 11343000 11000 28000 0 558000 54000 104000 -1438000 29000 6000 724000 -17000 -507000 6286000 292000 8837000 9661000 307000 368000 5611000 318000 367000 8708000 6157000 299000 5482000 306000 1608000 1133000 102000 2608000 98000 127000 2395000 82000 292000 523000 138000 180000 129000 1000 19000 129000 129000 1000 46000 -51000 -73000 41110000 41110000 0 0 0 <div style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; text-indent: 0pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; font-weight: bold; margin-right: 0pt;">(5)&#160;&#160;Transactions with Affiliates</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The late Mr. K. S. Adams, Jr., former Chairman of the Board and certain of his family partnerships and affiliates have participated as working interest owners with the Company&#8217;s subsidiary, Adams Resources Exploration Corporation (&#8223;AREC&#8221;).&#160;&#160;Mr. Adams and the affiliates participated on terms similar to those afforded other non-affiliated working interest owners.&#160;&#160;While the affiliates have generally maintained their existing property interest, they have not participated in any such transactions originating after the death of Mr. Adams in October 2013.&#160;&#160;As of December 31, 2014 and 2013, the Company owed a combined net total of $51,000 and $38,000, respectively, to these related parties.&#160;&#160;In connection with the operation of certain oil and gas properties, the Company also charges such related parties for administrative overhead primarily as prescribed by the Council of Petroleum Accountants Society Bulletin 5. Such overhead recoveries totaled $151,000, $152,000 and $152,000 for the years ended December 31, 2014, 2013, and 2012, respectively.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The Company also enters into certain transactions in the normal course of business with other affiliated entities including direct cost reimbursement for shared phone and administrative services.&#160;&#160;For the years ended December 31, 2014, 2013 and 2012, the affiliated entities charged the Company $65,000, $69,000 and $64,000, respectively, of expense reimbursement and the Company charged the affiliates $42,000, $99,000 and $98,000, respectively, for such expense reimbursements. The Company also leases its corporate office space in a building operated by an affiliated entity.&#160;&#160;The lease rental rate was determined by an independent appraisal.&#160;&#160;Rental expense paid to the related party for 2014 and 2013 totaled $607,000 and $481,000, respectively.&#160;&#160;Additionally, in 2014, the Company engaged a professional services firm controlled by Townes Pressler, a member of the Company&#8217;s Board of Directors, to conduct a crude oil supply availability study.&#160;&#160;Total study costs incurred were $70,420.</div></div> 65000 152000 69000 152000 151000 64000 98000 42000 99000 233000 43000 1034000 <div style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The results of oil and gas producing activities, excluding corporate overhead and interest costs, are as follows <font style="display: inline; font-weight: bold;">(in thousands):</font></div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: left;"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font-family: times new roman; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td></tr></table></div></div> 1619000 1151000 5054000 5756000 6771000 7091000 15954000 14129000 13361000 4001000 1373000 4699000 -7510000 -3632000 -2113000 -2628000 -739000 -1271000 -2361000 -1374000 -4882000 7573000 8848000 7494000 145382000 142570000 <div style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Revenue Recognition</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Commodity purchase and sale contracts utilized by the Company&#8217;s marketing business generally qualify as derivative instruments with certain specifically identified crude oil contracts designated as trading activities.&#160;&#160;From the time of contract origination, such trading activity contracts are marked-to-market and recorded on a net revenue basis in the accompanying consolidated financial statements.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Most all crude oil purchase and sale contracts qualify and are designated as non-trading activities and the Company considers such contracts as normal purchases and sales activity.&#160;&#160;For normal purchases and sales the Company&#8217;s customers are invoiced monthly based upon contractually agreed upon terms with revenue recognized in the month in which the physical product is delivered to the customer.&#160;&#160;Such sales are recorded gross in the financial statements because the Company takes title, has risk of loss for the products, is the primary obligor for the purchase, establishes the sale price independently with a third party, and maintains credit risk associated with the sale of the product.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Certain crude oil contracts may be with a single counterparty to provide for similar quantities of crude oil to be bought and sold at different locations.&#160;&#160;These contracts are entered into for a variety of reasons, including effecting the transportation of the commodity, to minimize credit exposure, and/or to meet the competitive demands of the customer.&#160;&#160;Such buy/sell arrangements are reflected on a net revenue basis in the accompanying consolidated financial statements.&#160;&#160;Reporting such crude oil contracts on a gross revenue basis would increase the Company&#8217;s reported revenues by $1,272,034,000, $1,602,626,000 and $1,381,352,000 for the years ended December&#160;31,&#160;2014, 2013 and 2012, respectively.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Transportation segment customers are invoiced, and the related revenue is recognized as the service is provided. Oil and gas revenue from the Company&#8217;s interests in producing wells is recognized as title and physical possession of the oil and gas passes to the purchaser.</div></div> 3945969000 4132826000 3376085000 68968000 67183000 14129000 3945969000 15954000 13361000 4132826000 3376085000 68783000 3292948000 4050497000 3863057000 1060340000 965098000 952435000 1173970000 949189000 849736000 968096000 1159931000 -940000 -3624000 2460000 8953000 8373000 6590000 <div style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The accompanying consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Adams Resources &amp; Energy, Inc., a Delaware corporation (&#8223;ARE&#8221;) together with its wholly owned subsidiaries (the &#8223;Company&#8221;) after elimination of all intercompany accounts and transactions.&#160;&#160;The impact on the accompanying financial statements of events occurring after December 31, 2014 was evaluated through the date of issuance of these financial statements.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Nature of Operations</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The Company is engaged in the business of crude oil marketing, tank truck transportation of liquid chemicals, and oil and gas exploration and production.&#160;&#160;Its primary area of operation is within a 1,000 mile radius of Houston, Texas.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Cash and Cash Equivalents</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Cash and cash equivalents include any Treasury bill, commercial paper, money market fund or federal funds with maturity of 90 days or less.&#160;&#160;Depending on cash availability and market conditions, investments in corporate and municipal bonds, which are classified as investments in marketable securities, may also be made from time to time.&#160;&#160;Cash and cash equivalents are maintained with major financial institutions and such deposits may exceed the amount of federally backed insurance provided.&#160;&#160;While the Company regularly monitors the financial stability of such institutions, cash and cash equivalents ultimately remain at risk subject to the financial viability of such institutions.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Marketable Securities</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">From time to time, the Company may invest in marketable securities consisting of investment grade corporate bonds traded in liquid markets.&#160;&#160;Such bonds are held for the purpose of investing in liquid funds and are not generally intended to be retained on a long term basis.&#160;&#160;Marketable securities are initially recognized at acquisition costs inclusive of transaction costs and are classified as trading securities.&#160;&#160;In subsequent periods, marketable securities are valued at fair value.&#160;&#160;Changes in these fair values are recognized as gains or losses in the accompanying statement of operations under the caption &#8223;Costs and Expenses &#8211; Marketing&#8221;.&#160;&#160;Interest on marketable securities is recognized directly in the statement of operations during the period earned.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Allowance for Doubtful Accounts</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Accounts receivable are the product of sales of crude oil and natural gas and the sale of trucking services.&#160;&#160;Marketing segment wholesale level sales of crude oil comprise in excess of 90 percent of total accounts receivable and under industry practices, such items are &#8223;settled&#8221; and paid in cash within 20 days of the month following the transaction date.&#160;&#160;For such receivables, an allowance for doubtful accounts is determined based on specific account identification.&#160;&#160;The balance of accounts receivable results primarily from the sale of trucking services.&#160;&#160;For this component of receivables, the allowance for doubtful accounts is determined based on a review of specific accounts combined with a review of the general status of the aging of all accounts.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Inventories</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Inventory consists of crude oil held in storage tanks and at third-party pipelines as part of the Company&#8217;s crude oil marketing operations.&#160;&#160;Crude oil inventory is carried at the lower of average cost or market.&#160;&#160;Due to declining crude oil prices, for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 the Company recorded inventory liquidation and valuation losses totaling $14,247,000 and $3,824,000, respectively.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Prepayments</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The components of prepayments and other are as follows <font style="display: inline; font-weight: bold;">(in thousands):</font></div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: left;"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">10,940</td><td nowrap="nowrap" valign="bottom" style="text-align: left; padding-bottom: 4px; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="padding-bottom: 4px; text-align: right; width: 9%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">16,779</td><td nowrap="nowrap" valign="bottom" style="text-align: left; padding-bottom: 4px; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td></tr></table></div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Property and Equipment</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Expenditures for major renewals and betterments are capitalized, and expenditures for maintenance and repairs are expensed as incurred.&#160;&#160;Interest costs incurred in connection with major capital expenditures are capitalized and amortized over the lives of the related assets. When properties are retired or sold, the related cost and accumulated depreciation, depletion and amortization is removed from the accounts and any gain or loss is reflected in earnings.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Oil and gas exploration and development expenditures are accounted for in accordance with the successful efforts method of accounting.&#160;&#160;Direct costs of acquiring developed or undeveloped leasehold acreage, including lease bonus, brokerage and other fees, are capitalized. Exploratory drilling costs are initially capitalized until the properties are evaluated and determined to be either productive or nonproductive.&#160;&#160;Such evaluations are made on a quarterly basis.&#160;&#160;If an exploratory well is determined to be nonproductive, the costs of drilling the well are charged to expense. Costs incurred to drill and complete development wells, including dry holes, are capitalized.&#160;&#160;As of December 31, 2014 and 2013, the Company had no unevaluated or suspended exploratory drilling costs.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Depreciation, depletion and amortization of the cost of proved oil and gas properties is calculated using the unit-of-production method.&#160;&#160;The reserve base used to calculate depreciation, depletion and amortization for leasehold acquisition costs and the cost to acquire proved properties is the sum of proved developed reserves and proved undeveloped reserves.&#160;&#160;For lease and well equipment, development costs and successful exploration drilling costs, the reserve base includes only proved developed reserves.&#160;&#160;All other property and equipment is depreciated using the straight-line method over the estimated average useful lives of three to twenty years.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The Company reviews its long-lived assets for impairment whenever there is evidence that the carrying value of such assets may not be recoverable.&#160;&#160;Any impairment recognized is permanent and may not be restored.&#160;&#160;Producing oil and gas properties are reviewed on a field-by-field basis.&#160;&#160;For properties requiring impairment, the fair value is estimated based on an internal discounted cash flow model.&#160;&#160;Cash flows are developed based on estimated future production and prices and then discounted using a market based rate of return consistent with that used by the Company in evaluating cash flows for other assets of a similar nature.&#160;&#160;For the years ended December&#160;31, 2014, 2013 and 2012, there were $4,001,000, $1,373,000 and $4,699,000 respectively, of impairment provisions on producing oil and gas properties.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Fair value measurements for producing oil and gas properties that were subject to fair value impairment for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 summarized as follows <font style="display: inline; font-weight: bold;">(in thousands):</font></div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: left;"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font-family: times new roman; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Fair value measurements for producing oil and gas properties are based on Level 3 &#8211; Significant Unobservable Inputs &#8211; (see &#8220;Fair Value Measurements&#8221; below).</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">On a quarterly basis, management evaluates the carrying value of non-producing oil and gas leasehold properties and may deem them impaired based on remaining lease term, area drilling activity and the Company&#8217;s plans for the property.&#160;&#160;This fair value measure depends highly on management&#8217;s assessment of the likelihood of continued exploration efforts in a given area and, as such, data inputs are categorized as &#8223;unobservable or Level&#160;3&#8221; inputs.&#160;&#160;Importantly, this fair value measure only applies to the write-down of capitalized costs and will never result in an increase to reported earnings.&#160;&#160;Accordingly, impairment provisions on non-producing properties totaling $4,008,000, $1,257,000 and $856,000 were recorded for the years ending December 31, 2014, 2013 and&#160;2012, respectively.&#160;&#160;Capitalized costs for non-producing oil and gas leasehold interests currently represent approximately four percent of remaining unamoritized oil and gas property carrying costs and categorize as follows <font style="display: inline; font-weight: bold;">(in thousands):</font></div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: left;"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font-family: times new roman; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The South Texas and Napoleonville acreage areas have active or scheduled drilling operations underway and holding the underlying acreage is essential to the ongoing exploration effort.&#160;&#160;The &#8223;Other Acreage Areas&#8221; category consists of smaller onshore interests dispersed over a wide geographical area.&#160;&#160;Since the Company is generally not the operator of its oil and gas property interests, it does not maintain underlying detail acreage data and is dependent on the operator when determining which specific acreage will ultimately be drilled.&#160;&#160;However, the capitalized cost detail on a property-by-property basis is reviewed by management and deemed impaired if development is not anticipated prior to lease expiration.&#160;&#160;Onshore leasehold periods are normally three years and may contain renewal options.&#160;&#160;Capitalized cost activity on the &#8223;Other Acreage Areas&#8221; display: block;">&#160;</div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">During 2014, the Company sold substantially all of its producing property interests in Oklahoma.&#160;&#160;Proceeds totaled $1,731,000 and the Company recorded a $1,149,000 pre-tax gain from this sale.&#160;&#160;Also during 2014 the Company sold one-half of its interest in sections of its South Texas project interest.&#160;&#160;Proceeds totaled $1,509,000 and the Company recorded a $632,000 pre-tax gain from this sale.&#160;&#160;Certain other oil and gas property interests were also sold in 2014 for proceeds totaling $822,000 and gains totaling $747,000.&#160;&#160;During 2012, the Company sold half of its interest in certain non-producing Kansas oil and gas properties.&#160;&#160;Proceeds from the sale totaled $578,000 and the Company recorded a $475,000 pre-tax gain from this sale.&#160;&#160;Also during 2012, the Company sold its interest in two oil and gas producing property units for total proceeds of $3,049,000.&#160;&#160;The Company realized a $1,728,000 pre-tax gain from these two sales.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">During 2014, 2013 and 2012, the Company sold certain used trucks and equipment from its marketing and transportation segments and recorded net pre-tax gains totaling $1,028,000, $683,000 and $2,482,000, respectively.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Cash Deposits and Other Assets</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The Company has established certain deposits to support participation in its liability insurance program and remittance of state crude oil severance taxes and other state collateral deposits.&#160;&#160;Insurance collateral deposits are invested at the discretion of the Company&#8217;s insurance carrier and such investments primarily consist of intermediate term federal government bonds and bonds backed by federal agencies.&#160;&#160;Components of cash deposits and other assets are as follows <font style="display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td></tr><tr bgcolor="#cceeff"><td valign="bottom" style="width: 76%;"><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 18pt; display: block; font-family: times new roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Insurance collateral deposits</div></td><td valign="bottom" style="width: 1%; display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="text-align: left; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">$</td><td valign="bottom" style="text-align: right; width: 9%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">4,536</td><td nowrap="nowrap" valign="bottom" style="text-align: left; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">$</td><td valign="bottom" style="text-align: right; width: 9%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">3,718</td><td nowrap="nowrap" valign="bottom" style="text-align: left; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td></tr><tr bgcolor="white"><td valign="bottom" style="width: 76%;"><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 18pt; display: block; font-family: times new roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">State collateral deposits</div></td><td valign="bottom" style="width: 1%; display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="text-align: left; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="text-align: right; width: 9%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">155</td><td nowrap="nowrap" valign="bottom" style="text-align: left; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="width: 1%; display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="text-align: left; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="text-align: right; width: 9%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">160</td><td nowrap="nowrap" valign="bottom" style="text-align: left; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td></tr><tr bgcolor="#cceeff"><td valign="bottom" style="padding-bottom: 2px; width: 76%;"><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 18pt; display: block; font-family: times new roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Materials and supplies</div></td><td valign="bottom" style="padding-bottom: 2px; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="border-bottom: black 2px solid; text-align: left; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="border-bottom: black 2px solid; text-align: right; width: 9%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">307</td><td nowrap="nowrap" valign="bottom" style="text-align: left; padding-bottom: 2px; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="padding-bottom: 2px; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="border-bottom: black 2px solid; text-align: left; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="border-bottom: black 2px solid; text-align: right; width: 9%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">609</td><td nowrap="nowrap" valign="bottom" style="text-align: left; padding-bottom: 2px; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td></tr><tr bgcolor="white"><td valign="bottom" style="padding-bottom: 4px; width: 76%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160; </td><td valign="bottom" style="padding-bottom: 4px; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="border-bottom: black 4px double; text-align: left; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">$</td><td valign="bottom" style="border-bottom: black 4px double; text-align: right; width: 9%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">4,998</td><td nowrap="nowrap" valign="bottom" style="text-align: left; padding-bottom: 4px; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="padding-bottom: 4px; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td><td valign="bottom" style="border-bottom: black 4px double; text-align: left; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">$</td><td valign="bottom" style="border-bottom: black 4px double; text-align: right; width: 9%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">4,487</td><td nowrap="nowrap" valign="bottom" style="text-align: left; padding-bottom: 4px; width: 1%; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt;">&#160;</td></tr></table></div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Revenue Recognition</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Commodity purchase and sale contracts utilized by the Company&#8217;s marketing business generally qualify as derivative instruments with certain specifically identified crude oil contracts designated as trading activities.&#160;&#160;From the time of contract origination, such trading activity contracts are marked-to-market and recorded on a net revenue basis in the accompanying consolidated financial statements.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Most all crude oil purchase and sale contracts qualify and are designated as non-trading activities and the Company considers such contracts as normal purchases and sales activity.&#160;&#160;For normal purchases and sales the Company&#8217;s customers are invoiced monthly based upon contractually agreed upon terms with revenue recognized in the month in which the physical product is delivered to the customer.&#160;&#160;Such sales are recorded gross in the financial statements because the Company takes title, has risk of loss for the products, is the primary obligor for the purchase, establishes the sale price independently with a third party, and maintains credit risk associated with the sale of the product.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Certain crude oil contracts may be with a single counterparty to provide for similar quantities of crude oil to be bought and sold at different locations.&#160;&#160;These contracts are entered into for a variety of reasons, including effecting the transportation of the commodity, to minimize credit exposure, and/or to meet the competitive demands of the customer.&#160;&#160;Such buy/sell arrangements are reflected on a net revenue basis in the accompanying consolidated financial statements.&#160;&#160;Reporting such crude oil contracts on a gross revenue basis would increase the Company&#8217;s reported revenues by $1,272,034,000, $1,602,626,000 and $1,381,352,000 for the years ended December&#160;31,&#160;2014, 2013 and 2012, respectively.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Transportation segment customers are invoiced, and the related revenue is recognized as the service is provided. Oil and gas revenue from the Company&#8217;s interests in producing wells is recognized as title and physical possession of the oil and gas passes to the purchaser.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Letter of Credit Facility</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The Company maintains a Credit and Security Agreement with Wells Fargo Bank to provide a $60 million stand-by letter of credit facility that is used to support the Company&#8217;s crude oil purchases within the marketing segment.&#160;&#160;This facility is collateralized by the eligible accounts receivable within the segment and certain marketing and transportation equipment.&#160;&#160;Stand-by letters of credit issued totaled $15.3 million and $14.6 million as of December 31, 2014 and 2013, respectively.&#160;&#160;The issued stand-by letters of credit are cancelled as the underlying purchase obligations are satisfied by cash payment when due.&#160;&#160;The letter of credit facility places certain restrictions on the Company&#8217;s Gulfmark Energy, Inc. subsidiary.&#160;&#160;Such restrictions included the maintenance of a combined 1.1 to 1.0 current ratio and the maintenance of positive net earnings excluding inventory valuation changes, as defined, among other restrictions.&#160;&#160;The Company is currently in compliance with all such financial covenants.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Statement of Cash Flows</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Interest paid totaled $2,000, $24,000 and $10,000 during the years ended December 31, 2014, 2013 and 2012, respectively.&#160;&#160;Federal and state income taxes paid during these same periods totaled $8,169,000, $9,949,000, and $12,650,000, respectively.&#160;&#160;In addition, State income tax refunds totaled $18,615, $4,000 and $10,000 in 2014, 2013 and 2012, respectively.&#160;&#160;Non-cash investing activities for property and equipment items included in accounts payable as of period end were $1,137,000, $1,507,000 and $2,419,000 as of December&#160;31,&#160;2014, 2013 and 2012, respectively.&#160;&#160;There were no significant non-cash financing activities in any of the periods reported.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Earnings per Share</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Earnings per share are based on the weighted average number of shares of common stock and potentially dilutive common stock shares outstanding during the period. The weighted average number of shares outstanding was 4,217,596 for 2014, 2013 and 2012.&#160;&#160;There were no potentially dilutive securities outstanding during those periods.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Share-Based Payments</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">During the periods presented herein, the Company had no stock-based employee compensation plans, nor any other share-based payment arrangements.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Use of Estimates</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.&#160;&#160;Actual results could differ from those estimates. Examples of significant estimates used in the accompanying consolidated financial statements include the oil and gas reserve volumes that form the foundation for calculating depreciation, depletion and amortization and estimating cash flows to assess impairment triggers and estimated values associated with oil and gas properties.&#160;&#160;Other examples include revenue accruals, the provision for bad debts, insurance related accruals, income tax permanent and timing differences, contingencies, and valuation of fair value contracts.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Income Taxes</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Income taxes are accounted for using the asset and liability method.&#160;&#160;Under this approach, deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized based on anticipated future tax consequences attributable to differences between financial statement carrying amounts of assets and liabilities and their respective tax basis (See also Note&#160;(2).</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; font-style: italic; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">Use of Derivative Instruments</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The Company&#8217;s marketing segment is involved in the purchase and sale of crude oil.&#160;&#160;The Company seeks to make a profit by procuring this commodity as it is produced and then delivering the material to end users or the intermediate use marketplace.&#160;&#160;As is typical for the industry, such transactions are made pursuant to the terms of forward month commodity purchase and/or sale contracts.&#160;&#160;Some of these contracts meet the definition of a derivative instrument and therefore, the Company accounts for such contracts at fair value, unless the normal purchase and sale exception is applicable.&#160;&#160;Such underlying contracts are standard for the industry and are the governing document for the Company&#8217;s crude oil wholesale distribution businesses. None of the Company&#8217;s derivative instruments have been designated as hedging instruments.&#160;&#160;The accounting methodology utilized by the Company for its commodity contracts is further discussed below under the caption &#8223;Fair Value Measurements&#8221;.</div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; display: block; font-family: Times New Roman; margin-left: 0pt; font-size: 10pt; margin-right: 0pt;">The estimated fair value of forward month commodity contracts (derivatives) is reflected in the accompanying Consolidated Balance Sheet as of December 31, 2014 as follows <font style="display: inline; font-weight: bold;">(in thousands):</font></div><div style="text-indent: 0pt; display: block;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: left;"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font-family: times new roman;
